case_name: Newspapers Ltd., Allahabad v. its workmen

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 213 of 1956 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 213 of 1956. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated September 22, 1954 of Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 8 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 22, 1954, of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 8 of 1954 arising out of the judgment

facts.text: Special Appeal No. 8 of 1954 arose out of judgment dated January 6, 1954 of Allahabad High Court in Civil Miscellaneous Writ Petition No. 651 of 1953.

facts.text: Tajammul Hussain, respondent No. 3, was employed as a linotypist by the appellant company.

anchor.surface_text: Tajammul Hussain, respondent No. 3 was employed as a lino typist by the appellant companypany.

facts.text: Tajammul Hussain was dismissed on May 8, 1952, on allegations of incompetence under r. 12(ii) of the Standing Orders of the appellant company.

anchor.surface_text: He was dismissed on May 8, 1952, on, allegations of incompetence under r. 12  ii  of the Standing Orders of the appellant companypany.

facts.text: Dismissal of respondent No. 3 was welcomed by his coworkers and other workmen in the employ of the appellant company.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged that the dismissal of Respondent No. 3 was welcomed by his companyworkers and other workmen in the employ of the appellant companypany

facts.text: Workmen made no grievance about the dismissal and did not espouse his cause.

facts.text: Case of respondent No. 3 was not taken up by any union of workers of the appellant company nor by any unions of workmen in similar or allied trades.

anchor.surface_text: The case of respondent No. 3 was number taken up by any union of workers of the appellant companypany number by any of the unions of workmen employed in similar or allied trades,

facts.text: P. Working Journalists Union, Lucknow, with which respondent No. 3 had no connection, took the matter to the Conciliation Board, Allahabad.

anchor.surface_text: but the P. Working Journalists Union, Lucknow, with which respondent No. 3 had numberconnection whatsoever, took the matter to the Conciliation Board, Allahabad.

facts.text: U.P. Government made a reference to the Industrial Tribunal on June 3, 1953 by notification.

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately, the U.P. Government made a reference to the Industrial Tribunal on June 3, 1953, by numberification the prefatory words

facts.text: Reference concerned industrial dispute between Newspapers Ltd., Allahabad and its workmen.

anchor.surface_text: Whereas an industrial dispute in respect of the matters hereinafter specified exists between the companycern known as Newspapers Ltd., Allahabad and its workmen

facts.text: One question referred: Whether services of Sri Tajammul Hussain Lino Operator were wrongfully terminated by the Management.

anchor.surface_text: One of the questions referred was- Whether the services of Sri Tajammul Hussain Lino Operator were wrongfully terminated by the Management

facts.text: State Industrial Tribunal at Allahabad decided in favour of respondent No. 3 on February 13, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On February 13, 1953, the State Industrial Tribunal at Allahabad decided in favour of respondent No. 3 and ordered his reinstatement

facts.text: Tribunal ordered reinstatement of respondent No. 3 without break of continuity of service and payment of wages for dismissed period.

anchor.surface_text: and ordered his reinstatement without break of companytinuity of service and also ordered the payment of his wages for the period during which he remained dismissed.

facts.text: Appellant company appealed to Labour Appellate Tribunal, which affirmed the Tribunal's order by order dated February 24, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal was taken by the appellant companypany to the Labour Appellate Tribunal, who by its ,order dated February 24, 1953, affirmed the order of the Tribunal

facts.text: Appellant company filed petition in Allahabad High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution, dismissed by Bhargava J. on January 6, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companypany then moved a petition in the Allahabad High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution but this was dismissed by Bhargava J. on January 6, 1954,

facts.text: Special appeal against High Court judgment was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: and a Special appeal against this judgment was also dismissed. The appellant companypany has companye up in appeal

facts.text: Appellant company appealed to Supreme Court with certificate under Art. 133(1)(c) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companypany has companye up in appeal with a certificate under Art. 133  1   c  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellant seeks to set aside order of Industrial Tribunal on ground that no industrial dispute existed under U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The ground on which the appellant companypany seeks to have the order of the Industrial Tribunal set aside is that numberindustrial dispute existed within the meaning of the expression as used in the U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947

facts.text: U.P. Government notification assumed dispute exists between employer and its workmen.

anchor.surface_text: It may also be numbered that the numberification issued by the U. Government on January 3, 1953, already quoted proceeds on the assumption that a dispute exists between the employer and his workmen.

facts.text: Points of dispute in reference comprise wrongful termination of service of only Tajammul Hussain.

issues.text: whether a dispute between an employer and a single workman falls within the definition of industrial dispute as used in the U.P. Act

anchor.surface_text: The controversy which arises in this case is whether a dispute between an employer and a single workman falls within the definition of I industrial dispute as used in the U.P. Act. In order to resolve this controversy, it is necessary to refer to the scheme of the U.P. Act and the relevant rules made thereunder.

arguments.claim: English/Australian precedents: individual disputes not industrial/trade disputes unless espoused.
Prior SC cases support individual dispute becomes industrial if taken up by union/group.

holdings.text: A dispute between an employer and a single workman does not fall within the definition of 'industrial dispute' under the U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 unless espoused by the workmen as a body or a considerable section thereof.

anchor.surface_text: Thus viewed the provisions of the Act lead to the conclusion that its applicability to an individual dispute as opposed to dispute involving a group of workmen is excluded unless it acquires the general characteristics of an industrial dispute, viz., the workmen as a body or a considerable section of them make common cause with the individual workman

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of the Act, preamble, s.3 powers for collective matters affecting public order/employment, rules indicate collectivity, awards bind all workmen; individual grievance excluded unless group espouses it.

holdings.text: Rules 4, 5 and 15 of the U.P. Industrial Disputes Rules cannot form a valid foundation for including an individual dispute within the definition of 'industrial dispute'.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion therefore rules- 4, 5 and 15 of the Rules cannot be a valid foundation for sustaining the argument raised that an individual dispute was within the definition of industrial dispute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules must be intra vires and consistent with statutory scheme; cannot enlarge definition of 'industrial dispute' or s.3 powers; singular 'workman' does not override collective intent shown in r.26, s.18.

holdings.text: The jurisdiction of the Industrial Tribunal can be questioned on the ground that what was referred was not an industrial dispute.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Reference is administrative but party can challenge absence of jurisdictional fact (industrial dispute); citing State of Madras v. C.P. Sarathy.

holdings.text: No industrial dispute existed within the meaning of the U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 regarding the termination of Tajammul Hussain's services, as it was not espoused by any group of workmen or relevant union.

anchor.surface_text: The ground on which the appellant company seeks to have the order of the Industrial Tribunal set aside is that no industrial dispute existed within the meaning of the expression as used in the U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 (XXVIII of 1947) hereinafter called the U.P. Act and consequently the U.P. Government had no power to make the reference in question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied collective nature doctrine to facts: coworkers welcomed dismissal, no grievance or espousal by company union or allied trades; unrelated P. Working Journalists Union acted; reference concerned only one workman despite 'workmen' phrasing.

holdings.text: Swadeshi Cotton Mills Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen was not correctly decided insofar as it held that an individual workman's grievance is an industrial dispute.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of Act excludes individual disputes; s.33A introduction supports this; overrules contrary view.

anchor.surface_text: The words used in the first part of the numberification show that the Government was labouring under the misapprehension that this dispute was between the employer on the one hand and his workmen on the other, which, in fact it was number.

outcome.relief_summary: No industrial dispute existed as it was an individual dispute not espoused by body of workmen; tribunal lacked jurisdiction; reference invalid
